title: 109_s3490
content: The Act is titled the "Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge Study Act". It includes findings related to the refuge. Congress finds that the scenic Cherry Valley area in northeastern Pennsylvania is home to over 80 special-concern animal and plant species, including 6 endangered or threatened species such as the bog turtle, dwarf wedge mussel, and bald eagle. Efforts are being made to reestablish favorable conditions for the Indiana bat in the area. Cherry Valley in northeastern Pennsylvania is habitat for over 80 special-concern species, including 6 endangered or threatened species like the bog turtle, dwarf wedge mussel, and bald eagle. Efforts are underway to improve conditions for the Indiana bat. The area also supports 79 species of national or regional concern, including neotropical migratory birds, waterfowl, rare plants, and anadromous fish species. The Cherry Valley watershed in northeastern Pennsylvania is home to various special-concern species, including endangered species like the bog turtle and bald eagle. The area also supports globally rare plants, waterfowl, and anadromous fish species. Additionally, the Kittatinny Ridge within the watershed serves as an important migration route for birds of prey, including the bald eagle and golden eagle. The ridge also includes a segment of the Appalachian Trail, a significant natural and recreational feature. The Cherry Valley area in northeastern Pennsylvania is home to special-concern species like the bog turtle and bald eagle. The Kittatinny Ridge within the watershed serves as a migration route for birds of prey. Ongoing studies have shown high water quality in Cherry Creek. There are federally-owned parcels of land adjacent to the area for potential inclusion in a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Public meetings have shown strong local support for a potential Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, with landowners, leaders, and officials expressing enthusiasm for the project. Various communities and conservation groups share goals for protecting Cherry Valley. Numerous local communities, conservation entities, and landowners in Cherry Valley are actively conserving wildlife habitat and farmland. They, along with state agencies and the National Park Service, are potential partners for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Many local landowners have already placed their land in conservation easements or other arrangements. Several local landowners in Cherry Valley have placed their land in conservation easements or other arrangements. Voter-approved funds in Monroe County and Stroud Township have supported conservation projects in the area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "map" refers to the map titled "Proposed Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge-Authorization Boundary" dated February 24, 2005. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Study Area" pertains to the fish and wildlife habitat in Cherry Valley located in northeastern Pennsylvania as identified on the map. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the Study Area for potential acquisition by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service for inclusion in a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Consultation with State and local officials, conservation organizations, landowners, and interested parties will be done to identify eligible land and determine boundaries for acquisition. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the suitability of the Study Area for inclusion in a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. This includes identifying eligible land, determining boundaries for acquisition, assessing conservation benefits, and ensuring management in accordance with relevant policies. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the conservation benefits of establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, including preserving diverse populations of fish, wildlife, and plants, protecting habitats, providing recreational opportunities, and fulfilling international obligations related to wildlife. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the benefits of establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, including conservation, recreation, research, education, public participation, and acquisition limitations of 30,000 acres. A report must be completed within 1 year of enactment. The Secretary will complete a study within 1 year to evaluate the benefits of establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, including identifying specific land and water for potential acquisition. A report will be submitted to the Senate and House Committees detailing the results of the study. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the benefits of establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, including identifying land and water for potential acquisition. A cost estimate and funds from non-Federal sources will be provided for the acquisition and management of the Study Area. $200,000 is authorized for the Secretary to carry out this section.
